title: 4 Abus slain in Basilan clash
text:
4 Abus slain in Basilan clash By Roel Pareño   
Four suspected Abu Sayyaf bandits were killed in an encounter with government forces in Basilan on Wednesday. File photo 
ZAMBOANGA CITY, Philippines – Four suspected Abu Sayyaf bandits were killed in an encounter with government forces in Basilan on Wednesday. 
Senior Superintendent Nixon Muksan, Basilan police director, identified two of the fatalities as Mobin Kulin, alias Mulawin, and Hadji Villamin Hassan. 
Police and military operatives were serving a warrant to arrest Hassan when they chanced on Kulin and two other suspects in Barangay Tong-Umus on the island of Tapiantana. 
Muksan said the suspects drew their guns, triggering a firefight. 
He said Kulin, who has a P600,000 bounty on his head, was charged in connection with the Sipadan kidnapping in 2000. 
Kulin was also tagged in the siege at the Dr. Torres Hospital and St. Peter Church in Lamitan City in 2001.   
Authorities said Kulin was also behind the kidnapping of plantation workers in Barangay Tairan in Basilan in 2001. Sleepless over kidnaps 
Defense Secretary Delfin Lorenzana admitted that kidnappings and piracy by Abu Sayyaf bandits are giving him sleepless nights. 
“They are actually giving me…a headache,” Lorenzana told a forum at Camp Aguinaldo yesterday. “Sometimes I couldn’t sleep at night thinking about how to solve them.” 
He said the number of kidnap victims increased from only 18 when President Duterte took office to 31 now, excluding 70-year-old German Jurgen Kantner, who was beheaded last month. 
“It’s very embarrassing to the whole world that the bandits are doing this. But we are doing a lot of things that are within our power,” Lorenzana said. 
He said joint patrols with Malaysia and Indonesia would be conducted to prevent cross-border kidnappings. 
Lorenzana said the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) would also put up a task force based in Bongao town and possibly a permanent division in Jolo. 
During his visit to Sulu on Tuesday, the defense chief said the AFP would dispatch additional military equipment and assets. He said more Marine troops would also be deployed if necessary. 
Lorenzana said Navy boats had been deployed to the area, even as he admitted that they have no fast seacraft that could run after pirates and bandits. 
He said the government is also considering the holding of next year’s Balikatan exercises in Mindanao. 
“Maybe we can swing these exercises toward the south to coincide with our fight against piracy and kidnapping,” Lorenzana said. 
National Security Adviser Hermogenes Esperon said the military is applying its full force against the bandits to meet its self-imposed deadline to crush the group in six months. 
Meanwhile, in Basilan, a bomb exploded in front of the Jose Elementary School in Barangay Matatag in Lamitan City yesterday. Another bomb was recovered in front of a church in Barangay Malinis shortly after the blast. 
The military said the incidents could be a diversionary tactic amid relentless military operations against Abu Sayyaf bandits. – With Michael Punongbayan
